repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Correspondence, writings, audio and moving image recordings, photographic materials, subject files, printed ephemera, art work, and other materials created or collected by Richard Erdoes (1912-2008), author of more than a dozen books about American Indian life. The collection primarily documents Erdoes's activities between 1968 and 1999, and is useful for the study of his writing process and research interests, specifically his work with American Indian individuals and communities. His papers also serve as a resource for the study of the peoples, areas, and subjects that he chose to research and record, and are particularly useful for research about the American Indian civil rights movement, twentieth century American Indian spirituality and religious practices, especially among the Lakota, and American Indian cultural revitilization efforts during the latter half of the twentieth century.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English, with some material in German, Japanese, Italian, French, and Lakota.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Richard Erdoes on the Walter McClintock Memorial Fund and the Frederick W. and Carrie S. Beinecke Fund for Western Americana, 1998-1999, and from the Estate of Richard Erdoes on the Walter McClintock Memorial Fund, 2010.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 317 (electronic disk): Restricted Fragile Material. Reference copies of electronic files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 36-41 (color transparencies): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies are available. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 99-173, 194-199 and 299-313 (audiovisual material): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Richard Erdoes Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library. Yale University purchased Richard Erdoes's copyright in the Papers in 1998, when the Papers were acquired by the Library. The intellectual property rights, including copyright, of individuals who wrote or spoke to Erdoes belong to them or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Richard Erdoes Papers. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Richard Erdoes Papers contains material formerly classified as Uncat WA MSS 240, Uncat WA MSS 245, and Uncat WA MSS 248. Student assistants who helped process the Erdoes Papers include Tracy Garcia (Navajo), Basie Gitlin, Joel Vargas, Janine Polak, and Tricia Ross.

Audio recordings in the collection were digitized during processing. Digital reference copies are now housed with the collection's original audiocassettes and reel to reel recordings. Containers for these recordings have been retained as they frequently bear Erdoes's notes and annotations.

Film in the collection was also digitized. Digital reference copies are now housed in the collection; the original film has been placed in cold storage. Betacam SP videotapes were also produced during reformatting and are available for staff use if higher-quality copies are required by researchers.

The bulk of transparencies and 35mm slides in the collection that document the American West or relate to Erdoes's work with and about American Indians have also been digitized. Identified copyright work from museums and libraries, as well as images of trips to Europe, the Caribbean and the East Coast, were not selected for digitization as they were considered to be outside the primary research scope of the collection at the time of processing. All original 35mm slides and color transparencies have also been placed in cold storage for long-term preservation.

The 2010 Addition, described separately in the list below, received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization, in 2014. The Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section for this addition are drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Richard Erdoes (1912-2008)
bioghist.p: Richard Erdoes, illustrator, photographer, and author of more than a dozen books about American Indian life, was born in Vienna, Austria to Maria Josefa Schrom on July 7, 1912. His father, Richard, was a Hungarian opera singer who had passed away a few months earlier. Upon his birth, his mother joined the household of her sister, the German actress Leopoldine ("Poldi") Sangora. Erdoes spent his childhood surrounded by theatre actors and moving from city to city—Vienna, Berlin, Frankfurt—settling wherever his aunt and her actor husband held lengthy engagements.

When the Nazis came into power in 1933, Erdoes was a student at the Berlin Academy of Art. He established a neighborhood underground newspaper in which he began publishing anti-Hitler cartoons and caricatures. Identified by the Nazis, he fled Germany as a fugitive at the end of 1933, arriving in Austria where he enrolled in the Viennese Kunstgewerbeschule to continue his training. In Austria, Erdoes honed his cartooning skills and supported himself as a caricaturist for Tag and Stunde , two anti-Nazi newspapers. When the Germans entered Austria in 1938, Erdoes fled again, first to Paris, then London, eventually arriving in New York a year later. He married his first wife, Elsie Schulhof (died 1940), shortly after landing in the United States.

Erdoes was welcomed into the German exile community in New York, and launched a successful career as a freelance illustrator and photographer. Over the next two decades, he contributed to publications like National Geographic , American Heritage , Stage Magazine , and Life Magazine ; created cover art for record albums; and began illustrating children's books. Erdoes met Jean Sternbergh (died 1995), an art director at Life , in 1945. The couple married in 1950, and had three children— David Richard, Eric Peter, and Jacqueline ("Jaki") Jean.

By the mid-1960s, Erdoes was illustrating and publishing his own children's stories while continuing to build his freelance career. During an assignment to photograph American Indian reservation life for Life , Erdoes became deeply intrigued by contemporary Native American life and spirituality. Outraged by his first-hand experience of conditions on reservations and fascinated by the American Indian belief systems he encountered, Erdoes wrote, illustrated, and edited a number of adult and children's books on American Indian cultures, folklore, and life over the next four decades. He became a passionate advocate for American Indian civil rights, and an avid documenter of tribal life and spiritual revitalization, particularly among the Lakota.

Erdoes and his family opened their apartment in New York City to Lakota visitors and other American Indians during the early 1970s, creating a well-known gathering place for American Indian Movement (AIM) supporters and civil rights activists. Erdoes also became involved in the legal defense of a number of prominent American Indian activists, including Lakota medicine man Leonard Crow Dog, after the 1973 stand-off at Wounded Knee. In 1975, the Erdoes family relocated to Santa Fe where Erdoes continued to write, illustrate, and advocate for Native peoples.

Erdoes's first book about an American Indian tribe was 1967's Pueblo Indians for the Young Readers' Indian Library series. In 1971, he collaborated with John Fire Lame Deer (1903-1976), a Lakota medicine man, on Lame Deer's as-told-to autobiography, Lame Deer: Seeker of Visions . Erdoes published five more as-told-to collaborative narratives with American Indian co-authors: Lakota Woman (1990) and its sequel Ohitka Woman (1993), with Mary Brave Bird; The Gift of Power: The Life and Teachings of a Lakota Medicine Man (1992), with Archie Fire Lame Deer; Crow Dog: Four Generations of Sioux Medicine Men (1995), with Leonard Crow Dog; and Ojibwa Warrior: Dennis Banks and the Rise of the American Indian Movement (2004), with Dennis Banks. Other significant book projects included American Indian Myths and Legends (1984) and American Indian Trickster Tales (1998), both co-edited with Alfonso Ortiz.
Richard Erdoes died on July 16, 2008 in Santa Fe, New Mexico.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Richard Erdoes Papers consist of correspondence, writings, audio and moving image recordings, photographs, subject files, and other materials related to Erdoes's work with and about American Indian peoples, particularly the Rosebud Lakota. The papers span the years 1920 through 2008, with the bulk of the material dating from the 1960s through 1999. Though materials have been arranged primarily by format and function, subjects and topics represented in the collection transcend this organizational system. For instance, individuals who Erdoes recorded and filmed are frequently documented by images in the collection, and in Erdoes's correspondence or subject files.

The papers contain source materials—recordings, photographs, and subject files—which Erdoes used in his "as-told-to" autobiographies and other works about American Indians. Coupled with drafts of his works in Series II, these materials document Erdoes's process of recording, transcribing, and compiling his books. The materials present in the collection are valuable not only as a resource for scholars interested in how Erdoes produced his most famous texts, but also for research about the subjects he documented. Erdoes's relationship with several key figures in the American Indian Movement (AIM) and the Red Power movement of the late 1960s and early 1970s allowed him to document important moments in American Indian civil rights history, including the occupation of Wounded Knee in 1973 and its aftermath. His papers include documents, photographs, posters and other materials related to the trials and imprisonment of Leonard Crow Dog and reveal Erdoes's advocacy efforts on behalf of Crow Dog and other AIM members. American Indian social and political issues are prominent themes in the papers, accompanied by Erdoes's documentation of both the daily life and spiritual practices of the communities and families with whom he worked. The papers are a source for research about twentieth century American Indian spiritual beliefs and traditions; the Native American Church; and American Indian cultural revilization efforts.

Correspondence (Series I.) reveals the Erdoes family's on-going friendships and personal relationships with American Indians, particularly the Crow Dog family, and provides a glimpse of the professional relationships that Erdoes maintained with the editors and publishers of his books. In addition to drafts of many of his works about American Indians and some of this other publishing projects, Series II. Writings includes research notes, film and book proposals, published editions, book reviews, ephemera and other material related to Erdoes's career as an author.

Photographic materials in Series III. consists of tens of thousands of color and black and white images (negatives, 35mm and glass slides, transparencies as well as prints) that Erdoes created or collected. The images primarily document Erdoes's interest and work about the American West and American Indian peoples, but images of his family and various European trips are also present, along with portraits, landscapes, and city scenes that may be representative of Erdoes's commercial work. The images showcase Erdoes's interests and his evolving fascination with different areas and people, tracing his travels and activities over more than forty decades; simultaneously, the organization of the visual materials, with caption information that Erdoes created, reveal connections that Erdoes made among his photographed subjects and in some cases, his understanding of their meaning. In addition to documenting Erdoes's work, the images themselves are a visual resource for the study of American Indian communities-- particularly Navajo (Diné), Pueblo and Lakota communities-- and the American West in the twentieth century. A selection document American Indian civil rights actions and tribal ceremonies. Many of these images are present because of the relationships that Erdoes built with various tribal leaders and medicine men, allowing him access to photograph events that he witnessed and in which he often participated.

Most of the ten 16mm films that comprise the Films series (Series IV.) document the Crow Dog family, recording life and ceremonies on the Rosebud reservation and at Crow Dog's Paradise; footage of Mary Brave Bird and a pan-Indian rights movement gathering are also present. Much of the film is spliced together and unaccompanied by sound.

The recordings in Series V. are a rich trove of audio documentation, consisting of over three hundred individual recordings. Interviews with American Indian individuals, including Erdoes's co-authors, prominent American Indian Movement (AIM) members, elders, and American Indian spiritual and political leaders are present, as are recordings of events, speeches, and ceremonies. Many of the recordings intimately document the perspectives and concerns of twentieth century American Indians in their own words. American Indian spirituality and traditional belief, as well as the practices of the Native American Church, are prominent themes. A Ghost Dance, likely Crow Dog's 1974 Ghost Dance, is particularly well-documented with forty-eight recordings. Other recurring themes include contemporary American Indian social, political, and economic issues, cultural revitalization efforts, and the American Indian Movement (AIM).

Erdoes's subject files (Series VI.) reflect his broad interest in American Indian issues, in particular his interest in contemporary news events. There are substantial subject files associated with Leonard Crow Dog, the American Indian Movement, and the 1973 Occupation of Wounded Knee. The subject files also contain transcripts of some of the audio recordings Erdoes conducted with his co-authors, and transcribed first-hand accounts of various events. Erdoes appears to have used his subject files as a structure to organize his transcripts topically, interfiling sections from various recordings by subject rather than filing transcripts by interviewee or date. A substantial clippings file is also present, and many of the materials in the subject files bear Erdoes's annotations and highlighter markings.

Erdoes's interest in the social and political landscape of American Indians is further documented by newsletters, magazines, fliers, ephemera, and other published materials present (Series VII.). Among these printed works are publications by European American Indian supporters, the American Indian movement, various tribes and tribal councils, American Indian student groups, and pan-Indian organizations; mainstream magazines profiling Native issues are also present. Many of the publications have an explicitly political angle, capturing the genesis, radicalism, and evolution of the American Indian civil rights movement and late twentieth century tribal revitalization efforts.

The papers include Erdoes's collection of broadsides, posters, and art works (Series VIII.) The series includes posters that Erdoes appears to have created for New York City events, as well as art work by Henry Crow Dog, and a series of drawings that are unattributed, but bear close resemblance to Erdoes's illustration style. Together with the photographic materials, film, and subject files, the posters position the Erdoes Papers as a resource for studying the representation and documentation of twentieth century Native peoples, particularly on the Pine Ridge and Rosebud reservations, as well as in Pueblos and other Indian communities in the American Southwest. The posters are also an important companion to the grassroots publications in Series VII; together, these materials showcase American Indian activism and community organization.

The 2010 Addition includes additional writings, photographic material, audiovisual material, posters, ephemera, and artwork that document Erdoes's collaboration with Leonard Crow Dog, Archie Fire Lame Deer, and Dennis Banks, his writings on the American Indian Movement (AIM), and his research on other aspects of Native American culture and history.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into eight series and one addition: I. Correspondence, 1964-1995. II. Writings, 1965-1997. III. Photographic Materials, 1952-1999. IV. Films, circa 1970. V. Audio Recordings, 1964-1996. VI. Subject Files, 1951-1998. VII. Printed Material, 1921-1998. VIII. Posters and Works of Art, 1967. 2010 Addition, 1920-2008.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I. Correspondence is organized into two subseries: General Correspondence and Third-Party Correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence in the Richard Erdoes Papers consists primarily of incoming letters to Erdoes and his family from American Indian individuals or correspondence about topics related to Erdoes's work, research, and advocacy for Native Americans.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Correspondence with publishers about specific titles may also be found in Series II. Writings , under the title of the work. Erdoes also often integrated his research and correspondence, which means that additional correspondence is housed in Series VI. Subject Files .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: General Correspondence is arranged alphabetically by correspondent's last name or the first word in a company title. Letters from correspondents not listed individually have been filed in "letter" general files. Unidentified correspondence has been arranged at the end of the subseries.
The file folders that Erdoes originally used have been retained in many cases, as they reveal Erdoes's organizational system and occasionally bear additional annotations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: General Correspondence contains incoming letters, both personal and professional, adressed to Richard Erdoes and his family from American Indian friends and contacts, as well as letters from contacts who assisted with his research and writing about American Indian peoples or assisted with his legal defense efforts for Leonard Crow Dog and others. Drafts and copies of outgoing letters, occasionally on the Erdoes family's illustrated stationary, are also present, though not in great quantities,

The correspondence reveals Erdoes's relationships, interests, and activities during the last half of his life, shedding light on his friendships with co-authors and their families, revealing generosity towards Indian people he befriended, and highlighting his activist efforts on behalf of American Indian peoples. Letters often relay personal news and reveal the living conditions and experiences of correspondents. A number of fan letters also reveal Erdoes's influence and impact on aspiring writers.

Correspondence of note includes copies of letters from civil rights lawyer William Kunstler concerning Leonard Crow Dog's legal case; the Erdoes family's multi-generational correspondence with the Crow Dog and Lame Deer families; handwritten letters from Mary Brave Bird to Richard Erdoes; and correspondence from an array of American Indian political and spiritual leaders, activists, and artists.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II. Writings , is organized into four subseries: Books, Proposals, Other Writings, and Writings of Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. consists of research notes, proposals, drafts, published volumes, book reviews, and other materials related to Erdoes's written works, as well as written materials by other authors which came to be in Erdoes's possession.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Books subseries is arranged alphabetically by title of work, with numerals in titles preceding alphabetic characters. Materials related to each title are in rough chronological order, with attention to the stage of the work and its likely order in Erdoes's creative process.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists primarily of drafts and published editions of Erdoes's book projects. Background materials, correspondence, and film treatments are present for some titles. The majority of works represented in the subseries are volumes related to Erdoes's work with American Indian people and subjects, although some humor books and non-Indian historical works, as well as a 1965 children's book Erdoes wrote and illustrated, are present. A number of titles also appear to have been unpublished, and are present only in draft form. Film proposals and treatments for a number of works are present, including Erdoes's corrections and notes for the film script of the TNT adaptation of Lakota Woman .

The manuscript and typescript drafts in the subseries illuminate Erdoes's editorial corrections and choices. Process materials in the subseries reveal the method that Erdoes utilized for transcribing and compiling his as-told-to autobiographies, which included transcribing recorded interviews and physically cutting and pasting portions of the transcription into drafts. Though some of these cut-and-paste drafts are present under the book title they relate to, Erdoes filed others in his subject files under the subject or topic being discussed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of poems, manuscripts, proposals and other unpublished works by authors other than Richard Erdoes. Many of the authors were correspondents with Erdoes, and their work may have been submitted to Erdoes for review or as a token of friendship. Other materials appear to have been collected by Erdoes as part of his research about American Indians.

Published works by other authors may also be found in Series VII. Printed Material
.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III. Photographic Materials is organized into four subseries: Negatives and Contact Prints; Transparencies; Slides; and Photographic Prints. Erdoes's system for organizing his photographic materials was idiosyncratic, relying on neither an explicitly chronological or topical order. Erdoes's organizational groupings were maintained during processing, though consideration was also given to grouping similar formats together for long-term housing. Folder titles based on Erdoes's original labeling have been transcribed and are indicated by quotation marks in the folder description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II primarily consists of original photographic work, both black and white and color, created by Richard Erdoes. Reproductions of images that Erdoes culled for research are also present, particularly in the Slides subseries, though not in great quantities. The photographic materials in this series primarily relate to Erdoes's interest and work about the American West and Native American peoples, but there are also materials that document his professional work as a freelance photographer and capture other subjects and locales, including images of his family, the Caribbean, New York City, and Europe.

There is some subject overlap between formats in this series, though most images appear to be larglely unique, appearing in a single format. The Photographic Prints subseries is an exception, as many of the images that Erdoes printed are drawn from negatives, transparencies and slides present elsewhere in Series III. Complementary sets of images in each format grouping may be identified based on Erdoes's titling, captions, and date spans.

Erdoes appears to have printed a selection of negatives, transparencies, and slides. These printed images (in the Photographic Prints subseries) appear to have been images that Erdoes chose for publication or exhibition, or which he particularly liked.

The materials in this series provide insight into the changing equipment, materials, and interests of Richard Erdoes, and provide a forty-year visual map of the areas he visited and the people he chose to document. The photographs in this series are a resource for the study of the locations and communities Erdoes captured on film, the people he met, and the events he witnessed and in which he often participated. In addition, captions of the images and the organization of his materials provide insight about the activities Erdoes used these materials for-- book projects, freelance assignments, exhibitions, personal recollection-- and the connections he made between images. Titles for groups of material likely indicate the main trip or assignment that images were associated with, but it appears that some later images were incorporated into earlier sets images or were misfiled. Erdoes's filing decisions have been preserved.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In this subseries, negatives and contact prints that Erdoes housed loosely in boxes are listed first, in chronological order with undated material following. Negatives and contact prints that Erdoes stored in binder pages are then listed, also in rough chronological order with undated material filed by format (35mm, 2 1/4, and collections of mixed formats) after the chronological sequence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of over 7000 black and white 35mm and more than 2500 2 ¼ negatives and contact prints documenting Erdoes's photographic work between 1952 and 1993. In general, Erdoes's loose negatives are works from early in his career, though there is some chronological overlap with material he stored in binders.

The subseries is dominated by Erdoes's documentation of the American West and Southwest, and traces the evolution of his interest in American Indian peoples and communities as well as travels in New York, the Caribbean and Europe. Erdoes had a particular eye for documenting the poor and marginalized in the places he visited, and his negatives capture community events, religious gatherings, local architecture and housing, monuments, landscapes, industry, and people's day-to-day activities.

Erdoes's interest in the Navajo (Diné), Peublo, and Lakota Indians are well-represented in this collection of negatives, with the earliest images of Navajo community members at a rodeo in his "West 1962" set (folder 27). Nearly all of the unsorted negatives document Western landcapes or American Indian peoples.

The subseries includes portraits and snapshots of many of the individuals Erdoes with whom co-authored his books, including Leonard Crow Dog and his family, John Fire Lame Deer, and Mary Brave Bird. Negatives are also present for pictures that Erdoes took of American Indian Movement leaders and various AIM protests in the 1970s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most of the contact prints that Erdoes housed loose in boxes are annotated on their verso with a number matching an accompanying negative; occasionally the title of the set to which they belong is also recorded. However, a few of the sets Erdoes created, including "West 1964," "Europe Very Best," and "Ireland," are annotated with more descriptive captions, occasionally identifying the subject or location of the picture. An estimate of the number of negatives and contact prints contained in each set has been provided. In cases where negative strips were enclosed in envelopes affixed with contact prints, the approximate number of envelopes has been listed.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Transparencies documenting American Indians and the American West have been digitized and are available through the Beinecke's Digital Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In this subseries, transparencies that Erdoes housed loosely in boxes-- these include both unmounted and mounted transparencies-- have been listed first, in chronological order with undated material following. Transparencies that Erdoes stored in binder pages are then listed. Undated sets of transparencies have been grouped according to subject, with transparencies of American Indian tribes, communities, reservations, and individuals listed first, followed by sets related to American locations, and then European locales.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder titles have been transcribed from Erdoes's original containers, and in instances where Erdoes sub-divided containers, his section labels have been transcribed in a folder note as "Captions." Estimates of the number of individual transparencies and in some cases, slides that were housed with his transparencies, are provided.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: 35mm slides that Erdoes created relating to American Indians and the American West have been digitized and are available through the Beinecke's Digital Library. Appraisal occurred at the container level. Images that were not digitized include Erdoes's slides of Ireland, Amsterdam, Florida, and the East Coast.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The slides in this subseries have been maintained in an arrangement that reflects the physical sequence of materials after rehousing was undertaken to prepare the slides for cold storage. Material in the original containers that Erdoes used to store his slide collection are in many cases housed in multiple boxes due to rehousing. A set of unmounted slides is listed at the end of the subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of more than 32,000 individual color 35mm slides that Erdoes prepared or obtained between 1975 and 1999. The slide sets contain both original images photographed by Erdoes, as well as reproductions of materials held by museums and libraries. The majority of images relate to Erdoes's American Indian work and his interest in the American West, though sets are present that document trips to other areas of the United States as well as to Ireland and Amsterdam.

Erdoes originally stored these slides in labeled plastic containers, which he further sub-divided into sets of images described with brief captions. Erdoes occasionally annotated individual slides with identifying information about the subject or location of a slide, but this level of captioning is not consistent across containers or sets. The labels that Erdoes gave to individual containers, as well as the image sets within, are transcribed in the box and folder listing below. Date spans have been estimated for sets, although the majority of individual slides are undated; periods represented from set to set, and from container to container, overlap. Provided dates may also reflect the year when a slide was mounted, rather than the date when the image was captured.

American Indian peoples that are particularly well represented in Erdoes's slides include the Navajo (Diné), Pueblo, and Lakota, though there are slides that document Cheyenne, Crow, Iroquois (Houdenosaunee), and Muskogee as well. Erdoes recorded the daily life and traditions of many of the communities and families he visited, though he also captured special events, inlcuding ceremonies, spiritual practices and community gatherings, as well as local architecture, arts production, and industry. Image sets related to his work with co-authors (Leonard Crow Dog, Archie Fire Lame Deer, John Fire Lame Deer) and their families are present. Erdoes also documented the physical traces of ancient American Indian civilizations, and seemed particularly interested in petroglyphs, mounds, and archaeological sites. Like his photographic work in other formats, the slides include portraits, scenic and landscape photographs, and photojournalistic work.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Unmounted slides are arranged in the order they were removed from existing slide sets. Each unmounted slide is labeled with its original set name in order to preserve provenance.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In this subseries, dated material is listed first in chronological order. Undated work is then arranged alphabetically based on Erdoes's labeling.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 524 photographic prints on paper and board and two photographic collages. Color images are present, but the majority of the images are black and white. Some of the prints are annotated by Erdoes, and bear captions on their verso. Photographs in "Acoma; Odd Photos and Historical" (box 92) appear to have been prepared for exhibition. Other photographs in this subseries bear publication markings or further printing instructions; a number of the images are photographs that Erdoes used in his books and in other publications.

The photographs primarily reflect Erdoes's interest in American Indians, and appear to be a collection of favored images from his vast photographic holdings. There is likely some overlap between the images present in this subseries, and the negatives, transparencies, and slides present elsewhere in Series III. Erdoes used broad categories to describe the sets he compiled, and some images appear in more than one labeled grouping.

In addition to sets of images documenting Navajo (Diné), Lakota and Pueblo communities during the latter half of the twentieth century, there are sets of images showcasing Erdoes's commercial photography, including nearly a dozen images of workers and oil rigs in Wilson Creek, Colorado (box 93); a selection of prints documenting the streets of New York City and the landscapes of rural New England and Nebraska (box 95); and a cache of prints documenting Erdoes's trip to the West Indies (box 96)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV. Films is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Films series consists of ten16mm films and three accompanying sound reels. Contextual and identifying information about the films is limited, but all relate to or document Erdoes's interest in the lives and traditions of his co-authors. Some of the footage reveals Erdoes's interest in documenting the sacred traditions and social conditions of American Indians in the twentieth century, particularly the Lakota, while other footage is valuable first-hand documentation of the American Indian rights movement in the 1970s. "Pix Reel 5," in particular, captures a gathering related to the pan-Indian rights movement and records a number of individuals talking about their reasons for being involved with tribal revitilization efforts. There is also an intimacy to much of the footage, which reveals the confidence entrusted in Erdoes by his American Indian co-authors. The filmed interview with Mary Brave Bird (folder #) is a particularly personal recording in which Brave Bird talks about the murder of AIM member Anna Mae Aquash, while preparing a meal for her family.

The films in this series have been digitized for access and to preserve content. The original film reels have been placed in cold storage for long-term preservation. Betacam SP videotapes produced during digitization are also available.
Reference copies are available in boxes 97 and 98.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV. Audio Recordings, is arranged into nine subseries: Ghost Dance, Leonard Crow Dog, Mary Brave Bird and Leonard Crow Dog, Mary Brave Bird, Henry Crow Dog, John Fire Lame Deer, Archie Fire Lame Deer, Other Recordings, and Filmstrip and Audiocassette Sets. Materials have been arranged based on the main speaker or interviewee, though many recordings include interviews or footage from multiple interviewees/speakers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The more than three hundred recordings in this series document Richard Erdoes's interviews and conversations with his co-authors (Leonard Crow Dog, Mary Brave Bird, Archie Fire Lame Deer, John Fire Lame Deer) and other Native American individuals, and are the raw material for his books about the Crow Dog family, as well as a substantial source of material for his other written works. Topics covered in the recordings, which include both monologues by speakers as well as interviews conducted by Richard Erdoes and others, are extremely varied, but certain themes re-appear: American Indian spirituality and traditions; the Native American Church; the American Indian Movement (AIM); and the social, political, religious and economic issues affecting American Indian peoples between 1964 and 1996. The recordings are particularly valuable for research into the production of Erdoes's texts, but are also a resource for the study of the subjects covered in the recordings; for research about the interviewees, who include a number of prominent AIM members; and for the study of how American Indians perceived the social and political climate in the United States in the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s.

Erdoes's audio recordings were originally recorded on both reel-to-reel tapes and on audiocasettes. During processing, all audio in the collection-- except for audiotapes in the commercial filmstrip sets that Erdoes helped produce-- was reformatted for preservation and access. Original recordings and containers are now foldered with digital surrogates, and the original formats listed in the recording's description below. The original materials have been retained because they often bear Erdoes's annotations, which include more detailed commentary and identifying information (not transcribed in this finding aid) which contextualize recorded content and often identify speakers, locations, and topics.

Titles for recordings are transcriptions based on Erdoes's hand-written labels, which either appeared on the recordings themselves—in the case of audiocassettes—or were affixed to the spines of containers which housed the recordings. When known, abbreviations in these transcriptions have been expanded; unknown, guessed, or expanded words in transcribed titles are bracketed or noted by a question mark. Ellipses indicate that title information was not completely transcribed. When dates could be assigned based on content, they have been supplied in brackets. Other speakers, additional content not indicated by the title, and sound quality information have been supplied as a note for some recordings.
Running times for recordings throughout the series have been rounded off to the nearest minute.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Audiovisual material. Restricted fragile. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Ghost Dance subseries is arranged in rough chronological order. Dates of most of the recordings in the subseries are not fully established, however, so the arrangement is also based on a numbering system present in the labeling supplied by Richard Erdoes. The subseries begins with a tipi raising marking the start of the Ghost Dance, moves through numbered Thursday and Saturday recordings, and ends with Sunday's meeting and other recordings labeled "Ghost Dance."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ghost Dance subseries consists of forty-eight recordings on reel-to-reel tapes documenting a Ghost Dance ceremony, likely the May 1974 Ghost Dance organized by Leonard Crow Dog, a year after Crow Dog's 1973 revival of the Ghost Dance at Wounded Knee during the American Indian Movement's occupation. The majority of the taped recordings span a long weekend, capturing approximately twelve hours of prayer and singing over several days. The tapes record singing and prayers in Lakota, and many of the recordings also include discussions or explanations in English about spiritual and political matters. In addition to the documentation of the Ghost Dance ceremony, a number of recordings at the end of the subseries document a meeting that may have occurred the same weekend, on the Sunday following the completion of the ceremony. Others record additional singing, praying, and interviews associated with the Ghost Dance ceremony. Of this last set of recordings, a number of recordings include interviews, including interviews with Leonard Crow Dog and with Henry Crow Dog, which focus on the Ghost Dance and its implications for American Indian peoples.

Topics range from discussions of Native American and Christian syncretism to explanation of the Ghost Dance and discussion of ceremonial objects. Some of the recordings of the Sunday meeting also capture discussion of contemporary politics, American Indian identity, the American Indian Movement, and the history of the Crow Dog family. Speakers are rarely identified, though Leonard Crow Dog and Henry Crow Dog are two of the main commentators. One recording from the Sunday morning set, labeled with the name "Bob" (folder 444), may be a recording of Robert E. (Bob) Robideau, AIM activist, speaking to a crowd of supporters. There are also a few recordings that appear to document other events, such as a presentation by Commissioner of Indian Affairs Robert L. Bennett to an unidentified steering group in 1968 (folder 428).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Leonard Crow Dog subseries is organized into three sub-subseries-- Interviews, Songs and Ceremonies; and Speeches. Within these three sub-subseries, the recordings have been arranged chronologically, reflecting the order in which Erdoes likely recorded the sessions. Undated recordings are listed at the end of each group. This order has been imposed as the recordings were acquired in different accessions, jumbled together in a number of boxes, with no apparent ordering by Erdoes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Leonard Crow Dog subseries consists of 68 recordings, acquired on reel to reel tapes and audiocassettes, recording interviews Richard Erdoes conducted with Leonard Crow Dog, songs and ceremonies performed by Crow Dog, and a small set of Crow Dog's recorded speeches and presentations. The recordings span more than a decade, from 1968 through at least 1993.

Additional recordings featuring Leonard Crow Dog are housed in the Ghost Dance subseries, and in the Mary Brave Bird and Leonard Crow Dog subseries. Additional recordings in other series may include songs, interviews and discussions with Crow Dog that were not identified during processing.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also: Ghost Dance and Mary Brave Bird and Leonard Crow Dog

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interviews consists of fifty-two primarily spoken word recordings of Leonard Crow Dog between 1970 and 1983. In these recordings, Crow Dog discusses his childhood and family, particularly his father and grandfather, and explores historical, social, and political issues relevant to American Indians, including the American Indian Movement (AIM); many of the recordings deal with his spiritual beliefs and visions, the Native American Church, the peyote sacrament, Crow Dog's role as a medicine man, and Lakota traditions.
Many of the recordings include other speakers, ranging from Lakota elders to AIM activists. Whenever known, additional speakers have been identified in a note.

Crow Dog also speaks about his daily life, the sacred peace pipe, peyote, alcohol, childbirth, and various visions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Summary: Starts with Sioux singing, Yuwipi songs. Leonard Crow Dog sings (accompanied by a drum), and tells several stories: one about a turtle encountering a buffalo skull, one about twelve warriors, and one about how the red trees once worshipped the Great Spirit. Crow Dog also describes how he became a medicine man, the dances he learned (including the Hoop Dance, the Eagle Dance, the Shield Dance, and the Rope Dance) and fasting

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Summary: Leonard Crow Dog and Wallace Black Elk discuss the definition of "Indian," their creation beliefs, war, and conflict. They also discuss the Thunderbird American Indian Dancers. Crow Dog discusses the death, autopsy, and burial of Pedro Bissonette, political elections and tribal leadership, the 1868 Fort Laramie Treaty, and warrants on the Rosebud Reservation. Crow Dog and Black Elk also discuss spiritual matters, speaking about a sacred gourd, the Sacred Pipe, creation, children, and language education, as well as UFOs. Black Elk discusses his commitment to Lakota burial and marriage traditions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Songs and Ceremonies consists of eleven recordings that Erdoes made of Leonard Crow Dog singing Native American Indian Church ceremonial and peyote songs. The earliest recording in the set is from 1968; the last dated recording is from 1983. The singing is often accompanied by drumming. On some recordings, a description of the song or an introduction has been recorded.

scopecontent.p: Speeches consists of five recordings of Crow Dog speaking publicly at various locations during the 1970s. His themes include religious freedom for American Indians, the federal government's treatment of American Indian nations, the American Indian Movement, the Native American Church, and his experience as a medicine man and spiritual leader.

Crow Dog also speaks about the "Christianization" and representation of American Indians, peace, his family, prayer, and sacred objects. Another man speaks further about Wounded Knee

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged chronologically. Undated recordings are listed after dated recordings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Mary Brave Bird and Leonard Crow Dog subseries consists of seven recordings which Richard Erdoes made of the pair during their marriage. Dated recordings span from 1975 to 1980. Three of the recordings are joint interviews of Brave Bird and Crow Dog, addressing personal topics about their lives and their relationship, as well as broader social issues, such as the forced sterilization of American Indian women, birth control, gender, violence, and spirituality. The other four recordings are of Brave Bird and Crow Dog singing and drumming ceremonial songs, mainly related to the peyote sacrament.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Recordings in the Mary Brave Bird subseries are arranged in rough chronological order, with some attention paid to internal organization systems that Erdoes developed based on alphabetical and numerical sequences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Mary Brave Bird subseries consists of 33 recordings of Mary Brave Bird, occasionally with other people, made by Erdoes and others during the 1970s, 1980s, and early 1990s. In many cases, particularly in later recordings, Richard Erdoes is directly interviewing Brave Bird or recording a conversation. Brave Bird speaks about her life, family, marriages, personal views and beliefs. Encouraged by Erdoes, who often focuses on details about ceremonial practices, religious symbolism, and on Brave Bird's memories of political events, Brave Bird relates specifics of Lakota and pan-Indian spiritual traditions such as the Sun Dance, Ghost Dance, and Yuwipi ceremony, as well as descriptions of the peyote ritual and Native American Church meetings, her life with Leonard Crow Dog, and recollections of specific AIM members and events. There is also an interview featuring Brave Bird, apparently made for a Virginia news broadcast (folder 541), and a recording which may be a soundtrack for a slide show or multimedia presentation (folder 548). The primary additional speaker in this sub-series is Brave Bird's second husband, Rudi Olguin, who is prominently featured in a number of the recordings in the early 1990s that Erdoes organized using an alphabetical sequence. These "alphabet" recordings appear to have been the raw material adapted for Ohitika Woman . The alphabet series also include interviews with Brave Bird's mother, Emily Brave Bird (folders 554 and 564), and with Brave Bird's brother-in-law and sister (folder 561). One recording features a joint interview of Brave Bird and a woman identified as Yossi Ramos discussing the Sun Dance at Big Mountain (folder 575).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also: Mary Brave Bird and Leonard Crow Dog
Additional recordings of Rudi Olguin are present in the Other Recordings sub-series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Henry Crow Dog subseries is arranged chronologically, with undated recordings listed at the end of the subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Henry Crow Dog subseries consists of 10 recordings of Henry Crow Dog, Leonard Crow Dog's grandfather. The seven dated recordings span the years between 1967 and 1981, and primarily record Crow Dog singing, praying, and performing ceremonies. The subseries also includes interviews that Erdoes conducted with Crow Dog for the book Crow Dog: Four Generations of Sioux Medicine Men . One recording (folder 591) features an interview with Mary Gertrude Crow Dog (1900-1987), Henry's wife, discussing how she met Henry, and recounting their early life together. Three undated recordings record mainly singing and drumming by Crow Dog.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The John Fire Lame Deer subseries is arranged chronologically. Undated recordings are listed at the end of the subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The John Fire Lame Deer subseries consists of 26 recordings of Chief John Fire Lame Deer, Lakota Sioux medicine man, all likely recorded during the 1960s and early 1970s. The recordings capture Lame Deer singing, praying, and describing ceremonies and also document interviews Erdoes conducted with Lame Deer about his life and religious beliefs. These recordings were a core part of Erdoes's research with Lame Deer for their 1972 book, Lame Deer: Seeker of Visions . The recordings, mainly recorded on reel to reel tapes, were likely all recorded before 1972, although most of the recordings do not carry explicit dates. The earliest identified recording is an interview by Erdoes from 1968, exploring Lame Deer's political and religious beliefs. This subseries also includes an audio recording of a television interview with Lame Deer, part of the 1972 publicity tour for Lame Deer: Seeker of Visions .

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Archie Fire Lame Deer subseries consists of 32 recordings of Archie Fire Lame Deer, son of Chief John Fire Lame Deer. The recordings document interviews that Erdoes conducted with Lame Deer, likely in preparation for Gift of Power: The Life and Teachings of a Lakota Medicine Man , the biography of Lame Deer that the pair co-authored in 1992. The eighteen dated recordings, which appear to have been made between 1971 and 1998, mainly appear to have been recorded in 1986 and 1988, during three distinct periods; the majority of recordings, however, are not dated.

In the recordings, Lame Deer discusses his personal life—his early education; his father, mother, and family; his employment history, including his service in the US Army and his work in Hollywood as a stuntmen; and his struggle with substance abuse—and shares spiritual, social, and political views. Lame Deer speaks about his role as a Lakota medicine man and healer, describing vision quests, sweat lodges, and Sun Dance, Peyote, and Yuwipi ceremonies. Lame Deer also recorded Lakota stories and songs, some with English descriptions, and talked about his travels in Europe and his work in support of Native rights. A number of the recordings deal with Lame Deer's focus on religious rights for imprisoned Native peoples, and there are also recordings where he discusses the American Indian Movement, Leonard Peltier, and the political landscape of American Indian political and religious rights at the end of the 20th century. One recording (folder 652) captures a conversation between Leonard Crow Dog and Lame Deer discussing themes related to education, Lakota spiritual traditions, and the study of Native cultures by non-Native academics, while another captures a three-way discussion between Erdoes, Lame Deer, and a man named "Andy," discussing travel and teaching in Europe.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Other Recordings is arranged chronologically, with undated materials listed at the end of the subseries. Because of the chronological arrangements, recordings with specific individuals are not necessarily grouped together as interviews or recordings may have occurred at different periods, and some recording sessions may be undated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Other Recordings consists of 134 recordings and includes interviews that Erdoes made with various subjects from the late 1960s to the early 1990s, as well as recordings that Erdoes made or accumulated during the course of his work during the same period. The recordings in this subseries reflect trends in Erdoes's research and methodology over time, documenting both his relationships with specific individuals and his interest in particular topics—Native spirituality, the Native American Church, social justice for American Indians, Native American stories, and the American Indian civil rights movement. Individually, the recordings document the attitudes, thoughts, and beliefs of various American Indian peoples during the period, and offer insight into personal responses to the socio-political status of American Indians and to political events during the genesis and early days of the American Indian Movement. A number of the recordings deal with the 1973 occupation of Wounded Knee, South Dakota, and the occupation's political and legal impact. Recordings that document spiritual ceremonies, powwows, and other events are also present, and several of the recordings record tribal members, particularly elders and/or spiritual leaders, speaking in their native language (Lakota, Cheyenne, etc.). Recordings often feature multiple interviews or recorded sessions spliced together.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Running time: 16 minutes

Summary: A 71 year old Lakota woman, Nancy White Horse ("Nancetentok") discusses her family and her own life, and is interviewed by Robert Burnette about various customs and traditions. At approximately 9.0, a monologue by Burnette begins, likely intended as a radio broadcast. Burnette speaks about life and issues for American Indians living on reservations, speaking about health and nutritional needs, government housing, and socio-political issues. Recording cuts off abruptly
Label on reel: "Nancetentok & Bob Burnette at Rosebud"

At 21:11, a recording begins of an unidentified Sioux medicine man, possibly John Fire Lame Deer, talking about his beliefs and spiritual practices. This recording also includes the performance of a number of songs, in both Lakota and German, and the recording of an indistinct conversation among a number of unidentified people

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VI. Subject Files is organized into two subseries: People, and Other Subjects. Each series is alphabetically arranged, primarily using the filing titles which Erdoes utlilized. As Erdoes often annotated and re-used folders, original folders have been retained. These folders reveal Erdoes's own organizational scheme, which has been preserved where possible and clarified where needed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject Files includes transcript material, printed ephemera, magazine and newspaper clippings, photocopied materials, and some correspondence. The diverse materials present in Erdoes's subject files represent the complex network of Erdoes's interests and influences over forty-seven years, from 1951 to 1998. The files almost exclusively document Erdoes's interest in American Indians and in American Indian issues, with substantial files associated with Leonard Crow Dog, the American Indian Movement, and the 1973 occupation of Wounded Knee. The Wounded Knee files are particularly rich, and include first-hand accounts from a number of participants as well as a substantial clippings file that documents how both the mainstream and American Indian media reported events.

Erdoes appears to have integrated transcript material into working topical files when compiling his books, filing sections from multiple recorded sessions about a specific subject together, often cutting up and photocopying sections to aid his work or create linkages between topics. In these subject files, some transcript fragments are clearly titled and dated, while others lack contextual information and may be difficult to match to a specific recording session. Multiple drafts and reproductions of the same document also appear in his files, usually annotated and corrected, and often accompanied by photocopies from reference sources, notes, and other materials. Transcript files of interviews with specific people are typically housed under the subject's name in the People subseries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VII. Printed Material is arranged alphabetically by author and title. Unsorted clippings and printed materials are listed at the end of the main alphabetical sequence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VII. Printed Material consists of newsletters, magazines, fliers, clippings, bumper stickers, and other commercially printed materials that Erdoes acquired related to American Indian issues and communities. The materials in this subseries date from as early as 1921 and as late as 1998. Among the materials are publications by European American Indian supporters, the American Indian Movement, various tribes and tribal councils, American Indian student groups, and pan-Indian organizations. Issues of popular American magazines profiling Native issues are also present. Many of the materials are explicitly political, documenting the social and political landscape for American Indians during the second half of the twentieth century, and capturing the grassroots movement and the more radical branches of American Indian pride movement that propelled AIM and sustained Indian communities during a period of intense tribal revitalization.

Many of the publications listed in this series are actually housed in Series VI. Subject Files . Their physical relationship with other materials has been preserved in order to maintain Erdoes's original organization of his records. Additionally, there are titles of some publications that have not been listed in this series, but are indicated by notes in Series VI.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VIII. Posters and Works of Art is arranged in chronological order, with undated works listed at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VIII. consists of Richard Erdoes's American Indian poster collection, some sketches, and a number of works of art. The series includes unsigned marker drawings of a Yuwipi ceremony that resemble Erdoes's drawing style, and may have been created by Erdoes as part of his research as well as paintings by Henry Crow Dog and an "S. Elk"
Dimensions for works of art have been rounded to the nearest centimeter.

did.unittitle: Crow Dog, Henry. Untitled , painting on wood board. Signed
did.physloc: Stored in: Crow Dog, Henry. Untitled [in Series VIII]
Also stored in: Posters [in Series VIII]

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Posters, fliers and broadsides promoting American Indian Movement events and rallies; ceremonies on the Pine Ridge and Rosebud Indian reservations and at Crow Dog's Paradise; Wounded Knee commemorative gatherings; American Indian events in New York City; and environmental awareness. Includes Indian Power art posters ("Indians Forever"), anti-coal industry posters, and posters protesting the imprisonment of Leonard Crow Dog and Leonard Peltier

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Boxes 194-197,
Betacam SP Working Masters
, consists of videotape produced during the reformatting of 16mm film in this collection as part of the Library's preservation strategy for cinema film. The Betecam SP copies are restricted to staff use to create high-quality derivitives of the original film content. Digital reference copies of this material are available. Original film reels are housed in cold storage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials in cold storage are fragile originals, and may only be seen with the permission of the appropriate curator. Digital access copies are available in the main box and folder sequence for the film reels housed in cold storage. 35mm slides and transparencies that document the American West or Erdoes's work with American Indians have also been digitized.
